Authors: Rusmanto T., Soedarmono W., Tarazi A.
Title: Credit information sharing in the nexus between charter value and systemic risk in Asian banking
Source title: Research in International Business and Finance
Affiliations: Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Faculty of Business, Sampoerna University, Jakarta, 12780, Indonesia; Université de Limoges, LAPE, 5 Rue Félix Eboué BP 3127, Limoges Cedex, 87031, France
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Soedarmono, W., Faculty of Business, Sampoerna University, Jakarta, 12780, Indonesia; Tarazi, A., Université de Limoges, LAPE, 5 Rue Félix Eboué BP 3127, Limoges Cedex, 87031, France
Abstract: In this paper, we assess whether the link between charter value and systemic risk in banking is affected by credit information sharing at the country level. Using a sample of Asian listed banks, we document that banks with higher charter value exhibit lower systemic risk because these banks hold more capital. Nevertheless, we find that the self-disciplining role of charter value in banking is more pronounced for countries with lower depth of credit information sharing. Specifically, our findings also reveal that higher charter value alleviates systemic risk and increases capitalization, particularly in countries with lower quality of private credit bureaus. These findings suggest that higher charter value can be detrimental for financial stability due to an increase in bank systemic risk, particularly when private credit bureaus are of better quality. In order to overcome bank systemic risk, this paper advocates the importance of strengthening bank competition to limit charter value, in addition to promoting the development of private credit bureaus. © 2020 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Asia-Pacific; Bank charter value; Credit information sharing; Systemic risk

Title: The influence of good corporate governance, financial and environmental performance towards firm value: Case of manufacturing companies in Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Innovative Technology and Exploring Engineering
Affiliations: Faculty of Economics an Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communications, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Faculty of Economics an Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lisal, M., Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communications, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This study aims to observe and analyze the influence of proportion of independent board commissioners, the audit committee, board of directors, return on asset, return on equity and environmental performance towards firm value. Firm value was proxied with Tobin’s Q. The population in this study is manufacturing companies listed in Indonesia Stock Exchange year 2013 – 2017. The study used 18 sample companies from 160 companies. The sample was determined by using purposive sampling. The result of this study showed that proportion of independent board commissioners, audit committee and Return On Assets has a significant effect on firm value while the board of directors, Return On Equity and PROPER has no significant effect on firm value. © BEIESP.
Author Keywords: Audit committee; Board of directors; Commissioners board; Return on asset; Return on equity
References: Retno, R.D., Priantinah, D., The effect of Good Corporate Governance dan Corporate Social Responsibility Disclosure on Company Value (2014) Jurnal Nominal, 1 (1), pp. 84-103; Ardimaswardoyo, W., The effect of Financial Performance and CSR on Company Value on Banking Industry (2014) Jurnal Manajemen Dan Bisnis, 18 (1), pp. 57-66; Monika, M., The Impact of Financial Performance on Company Value in Manufacturing Industry (2014) Jurnal Manajemen Dan Bisnis, 12 (1), pp. 1-16; Almiliaspica, L., Factors Affecting CSR Disclosure, and the Impact of Company Size (2011) Fokus Ekonomi, 10 (1), pp. 50-68; Ghozali, I., (2016) Multivariate Analysis Using SPSS 23, , Semarang: Badan Penerbit Universitas Diponegoro; Anjarsari, P.S., Andriati, H.N., The Effect of Good Corporate Governance and Environmentsl Performance on Comapny Value (2016) Jurnal Akuntansi Dan Keuangan Daerah, 11 (2), pp. 52-59; Fiadicha, F., Hanny, R., The Impact of Good Corporate Governance, Corporate Social Responsibility and Financila Performance on Company Value (2016) Jurnal Akuntansi Manajerial, 1 (1), pp. 22-45; Sucuahi, W., Cambarihan, J.M., Influence of Profitability to the Firm Value of Diversified Companies in the Philippines (2016) Accounting and Finance Research, 5 (2), pp. 149-153; Putra, I.P.M.J.S., Juniariani, N.M.R., An Analyisi on Financial Performance Ratio Towards Company (2017) Jurnal Riset Akuntansi, 7 (2), pp. 143-150

Title: The impact of CEO characteristics on earnings per share and earnings management
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Authors with affiliations: Putri, E.A., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Rusmanto, T., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The purposes of research were to examine the effect of Chief Executive Officer (CEO) characteristics’ on earnings per share (EPS) and earnings management. The research samples are 104 manufacture companies listed in the Indonesian Stock Exchange 2013-2017. Hypotheses test use multiple regression. The result shows that CEO’s narcissism, education, age, tenure, and nationality have an effect on EPS, while CEO’s gender has no effect on EPS. CEO’s narcissism and education have a positive effect on accrual earnings management, while CEO’s gender and nationality have a negative effect on accrual earnings management to manage EPS. CEO’s age and tenure have no effect on accrual earnings management. CEO’s narcissism has a positive effect on real earnings management; while CEO’s gender, education, tenure, and nationality have a negative effect on real earnings management to manage EPS. CEO’s age has no effect on real earnings management. © 2019 IJSTR.
Author Keywords: CEO characteristics; Earnings management; Earnings per share
References: Olsen, K.J., Dworkis, K.K., Young, S.M., CEO Narcissism and Accounting: A Picture of Profits (2014) Journal of Management Accounting Research, 26 (2), pp. 243-267; Resick, C.J., Whitman, D.S., Weingarden, S.M., Hiller, N.J., he Bright Side and the Dark Side of CEO Personality: Examining Core Self-evaluations, Narcissism, Transformational Leadership, and Strategic Influence (2009) Journal of Applied Psychology, 94 (6), pp. 1365-1381; Authors: Tamara D., Manurung A.H., Warganegara D.L., Rusmanto T.
Title: The determinants of financial innovation
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tamara, D., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Manurung, A.H., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Warganegara, D.L., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The importance of innovation in financial sector has attracted attention of scholars and practitioners. However, the scholar work of literature about determinants of financial innovation is incomplete and limited. This paper propose new angle from Resource-Based View to indicate the determinant of financial innovation which are innovation organization, skill, peer, information technology and firm size. Using sample from mutual funds companies in Indonesia and the method of partial least square to analyze data, this paper finds that innovation organization, skill and technology information are significant to financial innovation. This results indicate that premise of resource-based view also important to innovation in financial sectors. This paper contributes to the body of knowledge either in resource-based view literature and financial innovation in term of the discussion of determinants factors of innovation.. © 2019, IJSTR.
Author Keywords: Financial innovation; Firm size; Information technology; Innovation organization; Mutual funds; Peer; Resource-based view; Skill
Funding Text 1: This research received the Doctoral research grant year 2017 from Higher Education Ministry Republic of Indonesia.

Authors: Rusmanto T., Waworuntu S.R., Nugraheny H.
Title: Lead-lag effects in stock returns: Evidence from indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Nugraheny, H., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Abstract: The main purpose of this research is to determine the existence of lead-lag effects in stock returns in the Indonesia Stock Exchange. Fifty-eight companies were taken as samples, selected through industrial classification and selection criteria of leader and follower stocks. The data is analysed using Vector Auto Regression method to extrapolate and investigate the existence of lead-lag effects in Indonesian capital market. This study finds that returns to stocks with relatively high market capitalizations lead returns to stocks with relatively low market capitalizations in Indonesian industry portfolios. However, out of ten industries, there are only six who contribute significant result. This research concludes that lead-lag effects do exist in certain industries and it may assist investors in managing the trading strategy. Indonesian capital market is not efficient since lead-lag effects is one of the phenomenon, which against the EMH.
Author Keywords: Cross-correlation; Indonesia Stock Exchange; Lead-lag effects; Stock Returns
References: Boudoukh, J., Richardson, M.P., Whitelaw, R.F., Tale of three schools: Insights of autocorrelations of short-horizon stock returns (1995) Review of Financial Studies, 7 (3), pp. 539-573; Conrad, J., Kaul, G., Time variation in expected returns (1988) The Journal of Business, 61 (4), pp. 409-425; Fama, E., Permanent and temporary components of stock prices (1988) Journal of Political Economy, 96 (2), pp. 246-273; Fama, E.F., Efficient capital market, II (1991) The Journal of Finance, 46 (5), pp. 1575-1617; Gultekin, M.N., Gultekin, N.B., Stock market seasonality: International evidence (1983) Journal of Financial Economics, 12 (4), pp. 469-481; Haque, T., Lead-lag effects in Australian industry portfolios (2010) The Journal of Finance, 18 (3), pp. 267-290; Hou, K., Industry information diffusion and the lead-lag effects in stock returns (2007) Review of Financial Studies, 20 (4), pp. 1113-1138; Lo, A., Mackinlay, A., When are contrarian profits due to stock market overreaction? (1990) Review of Financial Studies, 3 (2), pp. 175-205. , http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/rfs/3.2.175; Mech, T.S., Portfolio return autocorrelation (1993) Journal of Financial Economics, 34 (3), pp. 307-344; Shleifer, A., (2000) Inefficient Markets: An Introduction to Behavioural Finance, , Oxford: Oxford University Press

Authors: Rusmanto T., Waworuntu S.R., Tjeuw J.
Title: Integration analysis’ explanatory power over stock returns: Evidence from Indonesia
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia; Tjeuw, J., Binus Business School, Binus University, Jakarta, 12070, Indonesia
Abstract: The main purpose of this research is to identify whether integration analysis for stock returns has higher predictive power compared to technical analysis and fundamental analysis alone based on research conducted in Indonesia. To fulfill the objective, the “blue chip” Indonesian companies are chosen. The research data period is 2007–2011 and taken quarterly. Technical analysis uses previous quarter return to predict current quarter returns. Fundamental analysis uses operating cash flow and price-to-book ratio. Integrated analysis combines these three variables to test the combined predictive power over current quarter stock returns. The results are compared using multiple regression analysis. Change in price-to-book ratio is significant and can help predict stock returns while previous quarter returns do not have predictive power of the next quarter returns, possibly due to the volatility in Indonesian market. Operating cash flow, while important, does not have predictive power over stock returns, possibly due to it not being an important factor in making investment decisions in Indonesia. Potential investors should understand Price-to-Book ratio and use it in any analysis concerning stock returns. They should also be prudent not to make investment decisions based on historical stock returns. Operating cash flow-generating ability is not one of the indicators the market watches out for. Integrated analysis outperforms a purely technical analysis, but not a purely fundamental analysis. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fundamental; Integrated analysis; Stock return; Technical
References: Bettman, J.L., Sault, S.J., Schultz, E.L., (2009) Accounting and Finance, 49, p. 21; Fama, E.F., Blume, M., (1996) Journal of Business, 39, p. 226; Liu, W., Strong, N., Xu, X., (1999) Journal of Business Finance and Accounting, 26, p. 1043; Jegadeesh, N., Titman, S., (1993) The Journal of Finance, 48, p. 65; Arena, M.P., Haggard, K.S., Yan, X., (2008) The Financial Review, 43, p. 159; Bonenkamp, U., Homburg, C., Kempf, A., (2011) Journal of Business Finance and Accounting, 38, p. 842; Alesii, G., (2006) International Journal of Business and Economics, 5, p. 245; Fama, E.F., French, K.R., (1992) The Journal of Finance, 57, p. 427; Margaretha, F., Damayanti, I., (2008) Jurnal Bisnis Dan Akutansi, 10, p. 149; Waworuntu, S.R., Suryanto, H., (2010) Jurnal Manajemen Bisnis, 3, p. 167; Clinch, G., Sidhu, B., Sing, S., (2002) Review of Accounting Studies, 7, p. 383; Habib, A., (2010) Australian Accounting Review, 20, p. 134; Penman, S., Richardson, S., Tuna, I., (2005) University of Pennsylvania, p. 5; Kim, M., Kross, W., (2005) Journal of Accounting Research, 43, p. 753
